dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A light rain. A SERVICE BAY. In the B.G. a YOUNG ATTENDAN 20s puts his tools away. An older man, M.A. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BOYETTE, 60s, station owner, puts a sport coat on over hi work clothes; then his watch. Calls out to someone in the office.

dialogues.speaker: BOYETTE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: You know what time I get up every morning, Hank?

dialogues.speaker: HANK, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: No idea sir.

dialogues.speaker: BOYETTE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Well, 4:45. Sun never ever beats me... Then know what I do at 6:15?

dialogues.speaker: HANK, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Listen to my radio show?

dialogues.speaker: BOYETTE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: On WSFA? ... Nope. I have my breakfast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boyette turns and enters the small office where he turns the YOUNG MAN and WOMAN he has been talking to.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Fair enough ... I guess we ain’t that big or we wouldn't be singin’ at that hour. HANK, a handsome, lanky 22 year-old, holds a cowboy hat. stares into the eyes of AUDREY MAE SHEPHERD GUY, 23. A go looking blonde with a hard side and a wicked smile.

dialogues.speaker: BOYETTE
dialogues.text: Nah, I’m kiddin’ around ... I listen to your program every now and then. Hank nods, smiles. Boyette’s greased-stained hands pick u sheaf of papers and flips through them. BOYETTE (cont'd) Hmmm... couple more little Justice of the Peace details. This your license and divorce decree, Miss Guy? Audrey takes a long look at the papers before answering. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: I’m Miss Shepard now. Guy was Erksine’s surname.

dialogues.speaker: BOYETTE
dialogues.text: But these divorce papers are in order, right?

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: They definitely are, Mr. Guy and I took care of that. You’ll take notice it’s notarized as well. She squeezes Hank’s hand in reassurance. He squeezes it b Their faces reveal a couple deeply in love.

dialogues.speaker: BOYETTE
dialogues.text: I see that. Just 10 days ago, huh? (sets the papers aside, picks up a Bible) Well, to the business at hand. Just because the ceilings aren't vaulted and the windows aren't stained glass, doesn't mean that this union is any less sacred. Now, before I pronounce you two sweethearts man and wife ... is there anyone here who has an objection, if so go ahead and speak your peace. The attendant enters. Laughter.

dialogues.speaker: ATTENDANT
dialogues.text: Not me, I'm fine about it.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Well then, let’s get on with it.

dialogues.speaker: BOYETTE
dialogues.text: Audrey Mae Shepherd Guy do you take Hiram King Hank Williams to love and honor in all duty and service. To live with him and cherish him according to the bonds of marriage.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: I sure will.

dialogues.speaker: BOYETTE
dialogues.text: And do you Hiram King Hank Williams, have this woman Audrey Mae (pauses)... (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BOYETTE (cont'd) Shepherd to be your wife and will you promise faithfulness in all love and honor and all duty in service to live with her according to the bonds of marriage.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: I will.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Through the sweaty, fogged window and the growing SOUND o POURING RAIN, the fading words ...

dialogues.speaker: BOYETTE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: By authority vested in me for the County of Covington, state of Alabama, I declare you husband and wife. You may embrace. Which Hank does. Long and hard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good sized kitchen as befits a BOARDING HOUSE likely buil the late 1890’s. Large table, a lot of linoleum, some smo wafting about and Audrey at the stove.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: (singing) “,... By a stream upon a meadow Under clouds white as snow I dreamt about you baby Even though you let me go” (takes a drink from a beer) Whatya’ think? Hank stretched out between two chairs, boots off, reads a Ranch Romance PULP COMIC BOOK. A five year-old girl, LYCR (Audrey's daughter from her first marriage)sits on his la trying to grab the comic. But Hank is actually reading an liking it. They tussle for it. A plain pocket-sized, overstuffed NOTEBOOK lies open next him. There’s an empty beer bottle on the table and he's drinking from another. Hank doesn't answer, instead takes a swig. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: How long it’s been since Lycrecia saw her daddy?

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: He's gonna stop by next week when she’s at mommy and dad’s. (back to singing) “ My heart is oh so heavy And my tears no longer glow I dreamt about you baby, Even though you let me go” So?

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: It's fine, baby.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: Fine?

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Yeah ... fine. As she puts a plate of overcooked collared greens on the table, a MAN, 50ish walks into the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: (rough) Who are you?

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: Raymond Wallingford. I'm a new boarder... are you Miss Lillie?

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: (nods towards Hank) Do I look like his mother?

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: No, uh, no, not really. Sorry ... Wallingford spins quickly, exits.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Raymond huh ... Seems like a fine fella. Hank sets Lycrecia aside, keeps reading the comic. He's really enjoying it. Laughs as he takes a bite.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: How’s the stew?

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Fine. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: Everything's fine? Even Raymond’s fine ... Hank gets up, gets some ketchup. Sits back, pours it all over the greens. AUDREY (cont'd) If it’s fine, it doesn't need any ketchup.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: It ain’t that fine.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: The food or the song?

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: (chuckles ) Well, they both need a little ketchup, honey.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: Screw you Hank.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: C’mon Auds.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: You c’mon... You always do this ...

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Do what?

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: Like you promised I could sing with you on the program and there’s been none of that at all.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: OK, fine.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: What’s that mean? Gets up, grabs another beer from the fridge, stumbles ove bottle and walks out the back door and down wooden steps the yard.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Jeeze, just what I said, okay ...

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (from inside) You think you're so high and mighty and it’s all you ... Well, I got ambition too and ... YOU quit goddamn acting like I can’t sing. Hank lights a cig, his back to the door. Suddenly one of boots nails him in the back. He calmly bends down and pic it up. The other one sails out. He just puts it on and mo out of range.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: (calling out) Yeah, that's a helluva song Audrey, now why don't you work on your sense of humor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Decent crowd. Music is number three on the list of import things in a joint like this: 1) illegal liquor 2) fightin then music.

dialogues.speaker: HERE INSTEAD
dialogues.text: “And we'll go honky tonkin’ honey baby, honky tonkin’ honey baby We'll go honky tonkin’ around this town Camera SNAKES THROUGH THE CROWD that has the air of dange that comes after midnight on a state highway in the middl the summer. Heavy smoke parts REVEALING creased faces and dirty fingernails; sandpaper hands cup beers and coke bot filled with cheap clear whiskey. HANK (cont'd) When you and your baby have a falling out Call me up sweet mama and we’ll go stepping out and We'll go honky tonkin’ ‘round this town ...” These are young rugged farmers and factory workers in the 20's, watching their women eat up Hank while they stroke their girl’s thighs. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HANK ON STAGE. He wears a Stetson, a regular suit and a loosened tie. Behind him is a version of his band the DRIFTING COWBOYS. Through the years the name would always stay the same, but the players would change 20 times. For DON HELMS 20’S on pedal steel guitar and LUM YORK, 20’S o bass; JERRY RIVERS, 20s and one other player (considering Sammy Pruitt). Hank hunches over the microphone, all 150 pounds of him. he sings, his knees buckle, his hips thrust. For these da it’s unique. Visceral. And the sexuality cannot be denied yodels, a WOMAN shrieks. Rest of crowd laughs at that. IN THE WINGS is Hank’s MOTHER, LILLIE, 40’s, intense, formidable and nearly as tall as her 6 foot son. She wear simple black dress and ARGUES with Audrey. They don’t now and never have, liked each other. Lillie FLIPS THROUGH the last bills of “tonight’s take.” actually starts counting the crowd.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: How much we got there, Miss Lillie?

dialogues.speaker: LILLIE
dialogues.text: I’m under no obligation to you.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: Right, that goes both ways ... he’s drinking like a fish tonight.

dialogues.speaker: LILLIE
dialogues.text: You think so ... ON HANK. Finishes the song, glimpses over at the two of t Nods for Audrey to join him. She’s pleased, Lillie’s not.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: Don't worry Lillie, Hank will hand it over to me before we even get home ...

dialogues.speaker: LILLIE
dialogues.text: I'd be careful little girl, that’s a tinder box out there. Hank grabs a coke bottle full of liquor off the floor. Ne falls as he does. Big swig, then drapes his arm around Audrey. He kisses her cheek, she leans into him. They rol into “BLUES COME AROUND” together. A SCARY GUY stands up in the crowd. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SCARY GUY
dialogues.text: Hey Williams, you sound like a billy goat. So does she. Hank ignores him.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: -.+. sit down you horse’s ass. Hank shakes his head at her. She knows better. The Man’s pulls him back to his seat.

dialogues.speaker: SCARY GUY
dialogues.text: So you hidin’ behind a woman ... You hear me you, you skinny little shit. Hank stops, shares a look with Audrey, a quick glance at Helms, then to the heckler.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: No, I can’t hear you. Starts the song again. GUY stands up again.

dialogues.speaker: SCARY GUY
dialogues.text: ++. every morning when my wife wakes up she’s listens to you on the damn radio, if she’s listening tomorrow mornin’ I’m gonna beat the hell out of her. Hank casually nods Audrey to step away. She hesitates, bu does.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: (smiles) Well, partner why don't you just turn the damn thing off ... that's why they put knobs on it. Audience laughs. The GUY explodes, CHARGES the stage, pus people out of the way. Hank shows no fear, just carefully sets down his guitar, goes straight for the LEG OF DON’S STEEL GUITAR. Crowd SCATTERS, the SCARY GUY trips, almost falls, gets t the stage, jumps up and dives for Hank. He just barely gr Hank’s PANTS LEG and pulls him to the floor. But as Hank down, he WAILS on the SCARY GUY with the steel guitar leg all gets bloody. Now Lillie wades in with her fists pumpi as Don and Lum try to separate them.  INT. LILLIE’S BOARDING HOUSE / BEDROOM - DAWN 10. Only a touch of morning light. Hank snores heavily. His pillow is spotted with blood. He has a Band-Aid on his ch Audrey is next to him, snoring even louder. The door opens and Lillie enters, stares, then gently sha Hank. Audrey stirs. Hank reaches over to wake Audrey. Lil quickly stops him. She does not want her along.

dialogues.speaker: I/E. ROAD / CHEVY
dialogues.text: TIGHT ON Lillie’s face as she drives fast. Her eyes a stu of reflection.

dialogues.speaker: LILLIE
dialogues.text: I know I birthed you Hank ... I was there. (chuckles to herself) But where you came from, how you got what you got and why you have it ... I swear no one knows that. Maybe the Lord ... Maybe. Hank now barely visible in the backseat. Hat pulled over eyes.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: (a hoarse whisper) She’s going to be pissed about this.

dialogues.speaker: LILLIE
dialogues.text: Think I care ... I’m doing everybody at the station a favor. That woman doesn’t have clue who’s the star ‘round here. And I haven't been driving you all over the state for 10 years, booking joints and schoolhouses to see her sweep in like she’s the Queen of England.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Yeah ... know why you and Audrey don't get along, cause one of you’s afraid the other’s gonna beat her to my pocket when I get drunk.

dialogues.speaker: LILLIE
dialogues.text: How can you say that? That’s hurtful, son. Lillie takes a corner and tires squeal. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Hey, I'm whupped ... that's all.

dialogues.speaker: LILLIE
dialogues.text: Wish that was all. When’s the last time you ate?

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: I can’t recall. They barrel in silence. Hank tries to get comfortable, stretches, puts his jacket under his back. Can’t. He’s clearly in pain.

dialogues.speaker: LILLIE
dialogues.text: Your back sore?

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: It’s fine ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A small studio on the second floor of the hotel. A MICROP says WSFA/NBC. The band is stretched out on folding chair behind it. Waiting. They sip coffee and smoke. Hank enters carrying his guitar case and is immediately confronted by the Station Owner, HOWARD PILL.

dialogues.speaker: PILL
dialogues.text: Williams, where you get off wasting twelve minutes of air time? That shit’s not gonna work. Hank turns, stares, says nothing. PILL (cont'd) -+. And you smell like a damn still. All of you. The guys stifle laughs, as Hank moves to the mic. Finally

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: I’m sorry Mr. Pill.

dialogues.speaker: PILL
dialogues.text: Well, that don't mean anything to me. Hank opens his guitar case while signaling to the enginee get things rolling. The band gathers their instruments. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Engineer, SEBIE SMITH, peers through the booth glass to P who has no option. Pill signals “OK” start the show. PILL (cont'd) I’1l boot you, I swear to god, I will. This is a business we're running, asshole.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: (dripping sarcasm) Oh I surely know that, Mr. Pill. Sebie counts it down ... HANK (cont'd) Hey, a fine very early good morning to all you friends out there. This is ol’ Hank and the Drifting Cowboys ... we’re awful sorry we're getting a late jump, but well, last night we got jumped ourselves out on Highway 31. (the band LAUGHS) I got a sore head and some other fellows in Alabama got some cracked heads. And oh yeah, there’s one more thing. This looks like it’s gonna be our last program here at WSFA. Hank smiles at Pill who’s staring back at him with disgus HANK (cont'd) And if any of you out there have enjoyed it, well, we’d like to sure hear from you. Now how about a little song I actually didn’t write called “My Bucket’s Got A Hole in It’...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Howard Pill walks up to two full U.S. POST OFFICE CARTONS next to a secretary’s desk. Bends down, shuffles through box that’s filled with letters to Hank. Walks away, says nothing. EXT. LILLIE’S BOARDING HOUSE - DAY CLOSE ON HAND. A stub of a pencil. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Hank isn’t writing, he’s just doodling in a notebook. (It ever present and full, with pieces of paper stuffed in it held together with a rubber band). He sits on the porch of Lillie’s BOARDING HOUSE. A few ot boarders are present as well. A cigarette dangles from hi lips, a beer by his side. A young girl, ELLIE, 20, sits down.

dialogues.speaker: ELLIE
dialogues.text: What you writin’ Hank?

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Ahh, maybe a little poem to the Lord, might turn into a song. Always use a new one.

dialogues.speaker: ELLIE
dialogues.text: Really ... Are you the religious sort?

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Well, when I was a boy I spent a lot of time in church listening to gospel.

dialogues.speaker: ELLIE
dialogues.text: You still are a boy. He reaches over and nonchalantly strokes her leg.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Think so, Ellie?

dialogues.speaker: ELLIE
dialogues.text: Why don’t you write me a poem.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Okay, but I might have to get to know you a little better.

dialogues.speaker: ELLIE
dialogues.text: (coyly) Sure, when? Lillie comes out on the front porch, walks over, takes th beer.

dialogues.speaker: LILLIE
dialogues.text: Get lost Ellie. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Ellie stands, smiles at Hank ... and straightens up as sh sees Audrey, who walks up carrying groceries. Hank, now f the two of them.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: You see Howard Pill called?

dialogues.speaker: LILLIE
dialogues.text: When?

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: ‘for I left. Says Hank’s gotta come back, he has a contract.

dialogues.speaker: LILLIE
dialogues.text: That’s true, we do. And it’s a good job right now.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: Says he’d like me to do some singing on the show.

dialogues.speaker: LILLIE
dialogues.text: That’s not true.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Jesus. I was doing pretty good here. Hank stands up, puts the notebook in his back pocket. Tak the beer out of Lillie’s hand. HANK (cont'd) A few more shows and I wanna be done with him.

dialogues.speaker: LILLIE
dialogues.text: It’s not that easy to get out of.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: Well, he can do what he wants, Lillie. Hank heads inside.

dialogues.speaker: LILLIE
dialogues.text: What is this, a schoolyard?

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: (back to Hank) Where you going? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Right now I'm gonna take a piss. And day after tomorrow, I’m going up to Nashville. Charlie Holt gave me the name of a guy who could help with the Opry. Audrey smiles at Lillie. Lillie cut

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: I been pressin’ Charlie Holt. You know that? You know that, right ..

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: LILLIE
dialogues.text: Well that’s swell, Audrey ...

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: Sounds good ... When we going, baby?

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Friday.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: Friday? Mom’s bringing Lycrecia back then. s a smile back at Audrey.

dialogues.speaker: LILLIE
dialogues.text: So there you go.

CAMERA QUICKLY follows JUD COLLINS, the Station Announcer winds his way through the buzzing halls. Glass windowed d bear the call letters, WSM “Home of the Opry.” He enters lobby. Hank smokes a cigarette, stares at a DJ through a booth window. Absently strokes the back of his head. Next to hi sits a beat up leather bag. A grey fedora rests on top of Hank turns

dialogues.speaker: JUD
dialogues.text: Hey there. , extends his hand. They shake.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: I'm Hank Williams. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JUD
dialogues.text: I heard that. Hank takes this in.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: I‘1l get down to it then. Charlie Holt gave me your name, Mr. Collins. He said you’d tell me what I have to do to get on the Opry.

dialogues.speaker: JUD
dialogues.text: (laughs) Well, there’s only one way to do that and that's audition for Jack Stapp.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: You know I sure hate those auditions, Mr. Collins.... Could I just meet him? Young SECRETARY in the hall calls MR. COLLINS, who signal just a moment.

dialogues.speaker: JUD
dialogues.text: Son, they’re no shortcuts to the Opry.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Then would you tell Mr. Stapp that I'm here.

dialogues.speaker: JUD
dialogues.text: Hank, how old are you?

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Twenty-four when I last checked.

dialogues.speaker: JUD
dialogues.text: Well, that oughta be old enough to know that's not how it works. You'll have to make an appointment, play for him and then if he likes it, you play for Judge Hay.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: And then what?

dialogues.speaker: JUD
dialogues.text: Then Judge Hay is likely to tell you to come back when “you're hot enough to draw flies ...” (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: I just might know how to do that.

dialogues.speaker: JUD
dialogues.text: Then you got a good start. Jud sizes him up, thinks for a moment ... JUD (cont'd) You know Fred Rose?

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Know of him. Roy Acuff’s partner.

dialogues.speaker: JUD
dialogues.text: Among other things ... Maybe you oughta know of him a little better. INT. FRED ROSE’S OFFICE - DAY

dialogues.speaker: FRED ROSE,
dialogues.text: mid 40’s, slight widow's peak, a keen visage that has no trouble holding an intense gaze. That said, his sm when revealed, is warm. There’s a piano in the office. He sits on swivel desk chair looking straight at us. Fred is being interviewed by a reporter WHO WILL NEVER BE SEEN ON CAMERA. His voice will be intelligible but muffle

dialogues.speaker: FRED ROSE
dialogues.text: Since you're asking me ... I think basically it’s impossible to understand why or what happens when an artist or performer captures people’s imagination. The drums start to beat and the message moves across the mountains. Of course, there’s no shortage of managers or publishers or press for that matter, explaining why so and so is hot, or proclaiming this fellow is going to be a star ... That’s an opinion ... (beat)and I’m familiar with a lot of them...

dialogues.speaker: INTERVIEWER
dialogues.text: But you obviously thought Hank had something.

dialogues.speaker: FRED ROSE
dialogues.text: Yes I did. It would have been hard not to... (MORE) (CONTINUED)

FRED ROSE (cont'd) When he first came to see me he played some of the songs he’d written, and some other folks material too. (Takes a beat) Actually I believe Audrey, his wife, had been calling here quite a bit, pushing me to see him... Anyway, I offered him a contract right then and there as a song writer. Twenty dollars a song I believe.

dialogues.speaker: INTERVIEWER
dialogues.text: .».. and to be clear, you’re a song publisher here in Nashville.

dialogues.speaker: FRED ROSE
dialogues.text: Yes ... (laughs) I was originally a song and dance man from St. Louis, via New York, but yes, Roy Acuff, who as you know has been a big Opry star for quite some time ... we have a company. (thinking, smiling) I really liked Hank right off. Maybe it was because he didn't give a darn whether you liked him or not.

dialogues.speaker: INTERVIEWER
dialogues.text: Don Helms says you’re the only one who he'd really listen to about his music.

dialogues.speaker: FRED ROSE
dialogues.text: Let’s put it this way he would listen to me. That doesn't mean he heard.

dialogues.speaker: INTERVIEWER
dialogues.text: Did you see, or rather what did you know about his ... problems?

dialogues.speaker: FRED ROSE
dialogues.text: All I’ll say is, as a young man I was personally no stranger to similar troubles myself.  19.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A ‘42 Plymouth rolls across a country bridge.

dialogues.speaker: FRED ROSE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: So I told him I was a Christian Scientist, which he was not likely not to know, and we assert that humanity is spiritual rather than material. That ... that faith has helped me through some dark times ++. and he should call me if he needed me.

dialogues.speaker: I/E. ALABAMA ROAD / PLYMOUTH
dialogues.text: Don Helms drives, a woman next to him. Hank is stretched in the backseat, head in Audrey’s lap, bare feet out the window. Radio plays low.(Probably a baseball game). Goes bit, then ...

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: A damn publishing deal. A publishing deal.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: Ten dollars per song, plus royalties.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: Officially ... a paid songwriter.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: That’s right, so I suggest you address me as Mr. Hiram Williams. Audrey leans over, tips up his baseball type cap.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: Where the hell did “Hiram” come from?

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: My old man. Got it from King Hiram in the Book of Kings. And then misspelled it on the birth certificate. Put in an extra “I.” That’s why they used to call me “Harm.” (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: Boy, Lillie never mentions your daddy at all, like he never existed.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Well, she put him in the Veterans Hospital in Pensacola when I was six. War injury from France or something, but some cousin told me it was from a truck accident at the lumber yard. Anyway, he was messed up and that was about it for us... after that ... well, I was pretty much my own daddy. Audrey takes a beat, strokes his temple. They laugh

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: I’m so glad we're taking a couple of days.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Yeah, me too.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN IN CAR
dialogues.text: Don’t you just love lightning bugs?

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: Love ‘em.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: Who doesn’t?

dialogues.speaker: HANK

dialogues.text: I’m sorry ma’am, there's still no answer. Would you care to leave a message?

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: Yes. Tell him, “I need to talk to you, you son of a bitch.” You got that? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MAN'S VOICE
dialogues.text: (stuttering) Uhh ... yes ma’am.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: Good and tell him “He can kiss my ass.”

dialogues.speaker: MAN'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Certainly.

dialogues.speaker: A BLAZING HOT SUN
dialogues.text: Seared across the SCREEN through waves of heat ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Through a window, a portion of a large crowd is visible. Sweating family faces, watermelon juice dripping off doub chins. Kids running about.

dialogues.speaker: W.B. NOWLIN
dialogues.text: (on the phone) Oscar, what the hell is going on here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The FARMER and his wife, who own the place and rock gentl a porch swing. Implacable... as they listen to a swearing PROMOTOR, W.B. NOWLIN, seersucker suit, sweat soaked, tal on the farm phone. Intercut with OSCAR DAVIS in a NASHVILLE office.

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR DAVIS
dialogues.text: You know how he can be.

dialogues.speaker: W.B. NOWLIN
dialogues.text: No, you tell me how he can be.

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR DAVIS
dialogues.text: Look, I can’t say where he is. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: W.B. NOWLIN
dialogues.text: Can’t or won't.

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR DAVIS
dialogues.text: Can't W.B.

dialogues.speaker: W.B. NOWLIN
dialogues.text: Why the hell not?

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR DAVIS
dialogues.text: ‘Cause I ain't his manager anymore. Son of a bitch fired me. Cold as night. Said I rode him about his drinking worse than his momma.

dialogues.speaker: W.B. NOWLIN
dialogues.text: Well, I’m not just the promoter here. I’m the damn Mayor and he doesn't show ...

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR DAVIS
dialogues.text: --- Sorry W.B.

dialogues.speaker: W.B. NOWLIN
dialogues.text: You should've called me and told me you were out. These people they don’t give a shit about your job they give a shit about where Hank Williams is? Hank fuckin’ Williams.

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR DAVIS
dialogues.text: Like I said W.B. I’m sorry. EXT. WILLIAM’S HOUSE (FRANKLIN RD.) - DAY Contrasting the expansive Texas field is a dark, rain fil sky. (STILL CONSIDERING RAIN AS MUSIC FESTIVAL MAY NOT BE

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: An ELDERLY MAN in a black raincoat and hat approaches the front door. He’s accompanied by a woman under an umbrella The man holds a DOCTOR’S BAG. He KNOCKS. After a beat, Mi Ragland answers. They enter. INT. HANK AND AUDREY’S HOUSE / BEDROOM - CONTINUOUS AUDREY O.S. That the doctor ... or whatever he is that does these kind of things? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The Doctor and woman follow Miss Ragland down the hall to bedroom. She slowly opens the door, reveals Audrey in bed Nervous. Whiskey on a bedside table. The Doctor hesitates But in true fashion, she stares straight at him.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: Well, come on in, let’s get this over with.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 1:45 pm Behind a makeshift stage. Crowd visible through scaffoldi Hank’s Packard LIMO drives into area at rear of stage. It trailed by a Police sedan. Packard stops, sits there sizzling in the heat. The POLIC CAR pulls alongside it. W.B. NOLIN gets out of the cop car, then the CHIEF OF POL Nothing stirs from the Packard. They walk over to passeng side. Jerry rolls down the window.

dialogues.speaker: JERRY RIVERS
dialogues.text: Mr. Nowlin?

dialogues.speaker: W.B. NOWLIN
dialogues.text: This ain't gonna do fellas ...

dialogues.speaker: JERRY RIVERS
dialogues.text: I’m sorry sir, he’s just come down with something and is too damn sick to perform up to our usual standards. Some fans start to run around the stage and crowd the car Nolin looks in past Jerry to see Hank in the back seat. H stares blankly back. Police Chief peers in as well.

dialogues.speaker: W.B. NOWLIN
dialogues.text: I don’t know what’s goin’ on with you Williams, but you’re going up on that stage and give these folks, who been waitin’ hours for your ass «+. a fine piece of yourself. You understand? Hank has no reaction.  63. INT. HANK AND AUDREY’S HOUSE (FRANKLIN RD.) / HALLWAY - D Darkness, cut by a single hall light. EERILY QUIET except the plaintive sound of Audrey WEEPING.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: REAR OF STAGE, Nowlin walks up steps. Disappears out fron Two other men follow, then Hank; glazed and deliberate. A the top of the steps he shares a look with Don.

dialogues.speaker: W.B. NOWLIN, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: (through a buzzing mic) Ladies and gentleman I have an announcement. Mr. Hank Williams is here ... and ready to give you the show you been hopin’ for ... Loud cheers, drown him out. He turns, stares back, waitin for Hank. W.B. NOWLIN (cont'd) Hank Williams folks ... Hank moves slowly towards the microphone. Behind him the pick up their instruments and begin to move into an openi number ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trying to focus ... crowd faces, angry, confused, some smiling, laughing, sweating, smoking ... His blurred gaze drops to the floor. He leans on the mic. crowd starts clapping. He looks back at Don, who is not s what to play, then turns back to the crowd.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: You know friends I wonder how many homes are broken tonight, just how Many tears are shed by some word of anger that never should have been said. ... (struggling) Hmmm ... folks ... hey ... do any of you out there know my very good friend Luke the Drifter ... well, Luke wrote these words ... Audience is now both captivated and confused. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: HANK (cont'd) I'd like to tell you a story of a family I once knew. We'll call ‘em Mary and William and their little girl Sue. Now Mary was just a plain mother and Bill, well he was just a usual Dad, and they had their family quarrels like everybody else. But neither one really got mad Then one day summin happened, it was nothing of course, but one word led to another and the last word led to divorce ... The band just stares along with everyone else. And Hank j drops his head, stops his drugged preaching and stands th totally alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don drives as Hank rests his head against the seat back, body half curled. In his lap are a dozen white roses. Han staring at the roses and realized something.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: You know there are 13 in here? Hank takes out one rose and sets it on the dashboard. HANK (cont'd) Thanks for doin’ all the drivin’.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: Sure. (Beat) Want me to wait around?

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Nah.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: Hope she’s okay.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Yep ... but I got a bad feeling, Shag.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: Like I said, hope she’s fine ... (Beat) Hank? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: I was thinkin’ ...

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Uh oh.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: Maybe I haven’t been much of a real friend ... maybe been too reluctant to speak up about some things, hard things.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: You been fine. Whatya goin’ do? After a moment. HANK (cont'd) You know my Uncle told me that Grant was drunk every afternoon by 3:00 ... but he still took Vicksburg.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: Yeah, I guess he did ... (beat) I’1l see you then.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: See ya. Hank climbs slowly out and walks towards the entrance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Audrey sleeps. A half-eaten tray of food next to her. No flowers, no cards. Hanks sits in the shadows staring at her through lidded e She wakes up.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Hey.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: How long you been here?

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: A little bit. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: Took you long enough.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Just got off the road, came straight here... How are you? She doesn’t answer, looks away.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: How’d you do?

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Made out okay... How’s my boy?

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: He’s okay... How much?

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Where’s he at?

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: The house, where you think?

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Billboard says we did 11,000 paid last week ...

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: Heard you and Luke had some trouble in Texas.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: (tries to smile) Yeah ... (long beat) What is it, baby? You gonna be okay?

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: Hell, you come home whenever you please from wherever you are and then we sleep together ... You don't have a damn clue. He tries to make sense of this. He’s swimming. AUDREY (cont'd) You did this to me, Hank Williams. You're the bastard caused me to suffer like this. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: What are you saying ...

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: You're barely here. You're barely even a father now and you can’t handle being more of one.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: My god ... what did you do? You can’t, you can’t do that without me.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: It’s done. We got nothing. You and I got nothin’. Hank squeezes his eyes shut, so hard, so pained, hoping w he opens them he’s not even here. The flowers lay across lap. INT. FRED ROSE’S OFFICE - DAY Another time, same Interview style - A RECORD is carefully placed on a turntable. The NEEDLE d on “Cold Cold Heart." For 15 SECONDS. Just the simple glory and crippling heart only Hank could render.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: “Another love before my time made your heart sad and blue And so my heart is paying now for things I didn’t do ...” From the spinning record to Fred’s face. “In anger unkind words are said that make the tear drops start How can I free your doubtful mind and melt your cold cold heart.”

dialogues.speaker: FRED ROSE
dialogues.text: What a truly powerful song ... If I was a betting man, which I’m not, I'd say three times a week we get a request to record it. Tony Bennett for one, did a heckuva rendition «+. you probably know that. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER
dialogues.text: Did Hank enjoy other performers doing his songs?

dialogues.speaker: FRED ROSE
dialogues.text: He loved it. If he came across a jukebox with a Tony Bennett version, he’d play it over and over.

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER
dialogues.text: Well, to say the least, it’s a very sad and painful song. Where do you think that came from?

dialogues.speaker: FRED ROSE
dialogues.text: .+. Being an artist, doing the writing, the composing, the real work, that itself can be pretty painful ... But I can’t really say .-.. family’s have pain, men and women cause each other pain, there’s physical pain ... but turning it into a poem like that, I don’t know.

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER
dialogues.text: You think he enjoyed his success?

dialogues.speaker: FRED ROSE
dialogues.text: I don't believe it mattered much to him. He wanted the Opry and he got it. But beyond that whether a song was number one or fifty ... he cared a lot more about just doing what he wanted to do.

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER
dialogues.text: And the money? The Wall Street Journal had his earnings at 150 thousand last year.

dialogues.speaker: FRED ROSE
dialogues.text: People like money. Some a lot more than others. Some it’s a way to keep score. He was fine just not having to think about it. He didn't do what he did for money. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: FRED ROSE (cont'd) The thing with Hank, he couldn't stop writing, he couldn't stop working. Whatever he had inside him he just had to get it out ... and of a body that was as frail as a baby’s. FADE TO BLACK.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY, ALABAMA
dialogues.text: An excited crowd streams in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STAGE WINGS. Lillie and Audrey and in between them, Lycre Junior waddles over to his grandmother. She picks him up. Audrey doesn't care for this, but puts up with it. She th turns around looking for Hank. This prompts Lillie to do same. MAN in a suit, obviously the promoter, walks to Audrey.

dialogues.speaker: PROMOTER
dialogues.text: We're alright, aren't we? Audrey gives him a strained smile.

dialogues.speaker: HANK SNOW, (O.C.)
dialogues.text: Thank you ladies and gentleman. And that about wraps it up for today. Crowd can be heard shouting “NO” ... “HANK, HANK!” HANK SNOW (0.C.) (cont'd) Oh right, there is a little more in store, isn’t there. I almost forgot about the man y’all have come here to say hello to and rightfully honor...  70.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hank palms a cigarette. His FATHER. LON WILLIAMS, 58, loo 70, his face with a slight paralysis, is also there. A lo silence.

dialogues.speaker: LON
dialogues.text: How many folks out there, son?

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Around 9000 they say. Lon nods in amazement. They sadly search for something, anything, to say. Filtering in from above.

dialogues.speaker: HANK SNOW, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: He’s my very very good friend, a young man with talent to burn. HUGE ROAR from crowd. Hank takes a long drag. HANK SNOW (0.C.) (cont'd) Maybe the finest songwriter I've ever had the pleasure to know.

dialogues.speaker: BACK UP ON STAGE
dialogues.text: Everyone there, all the family and friends, now wait anxiously.

dialogues.speaker: HANK SNOW
dialogues.text: Two number one hits on the charts right now, in fact. Let’s welcome at his Montgomery homecoming DAY «+. a great and loyal son of Alabama, Hank Williams.

dialogues.speaker: LON
dialogues.text: I’m real proud of you Hank.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Thanks Daddy, I appreciate it. A beat. Lon looks at Hank as the crowd sounds continue to build. It’s obvious he wants to reach out to his son. Han cuts a look up at the noise. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LON
dialogues.text: It’s awful good to see you. We probably should've done it more.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Yeah, don’t you worry about it, we got plenty of time ...

dialogues.speaker: LON
dialogues.text: I’m sorry son, I swear I am. He’s getting a little thick in the throat. This is hard.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: C’mon now ... aren’t we all (then) I better get up there... (smiles) +. ‘Fore they figure I’m too drunk to show.

dialogues.speaker: LON
dialogues.text: You probably got that right. Hank drops his smoke, crushes it. LON (cont'd) You look after yourself, okay? You look a little tired.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: (tight smile) Nah, I’m tip top.

dialogues.speaker: LON
dialogues.text: Sure you are ... (then) Hiram, thanks for allowing me to be here. Lon holds his hand out and Hank shakes it gently. CROWD CLAPPING LOUDER, INTENSE. Hank walks up the stairs followed at a distance by Lon.

dialogues.speaker: CAMERA FLOATS ABOVE THE AUDIENCE, PUSHING IN ON THE STAGE
dialogues.text: Audrey comes over, makes a show of kissing Hank. Lillie follows with an embrace. Hank moves to stage front. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Well, hello Montgomery. It sure is good to be back here and thank you all so much, thank you. And I much appreciate the warm welcome you've given my family, my mother Lillie, my wife Audrey, my big boy Bocephus. APPLAUSE with each of the intros. Junior now just runs to Lon, who scoops him up. Audrey quickly and with authority takes him away. Lon lets go easily. HANK (cont'd) Here's a little song been awful good to me and the family and the fellows behind me, The Driftin’ Cowboys ... It’s earned us quite a few beans and biscuits. It’s called “Good Lookin’ You Got Anything Cookin’, how’s about cookin’ somethin” up with me Hank stares at a crowd which is lost in him. Then turns t those behind him; the faces that rely on him most. Audrey Junior. Holds the gaze as his son smiles so sweetly. Then turns back to a throng, whose love for him is as unadulterated. It is a moment of true pleasure and peace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hank and Don seen from across 52nd Street in Manhattan. Amidst a crowd of midday New Yorkers, Hank, as always, st out. THE CBS BUILDING. A Black DOORMAN stands at the door chat with a young woman.

dialogues.speaker: GUARD
dialogues.text: Where you two fellas going?

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: Perry Como show. Guard gives them a once over and nods ‘em in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Old school bar. Hank leans over a cocktail table, WRITING a piece of hotel stationary. Don and LUM are sitting. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: TWO WOMEN walk past trailed by a BELL HOP with their lugg

dialogues.speaker: LUM
dialogues.text: Evening ladies. First woman stops and smiles, a half nod. Slightly curiou Second woman gives scant attention and keeps moving.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: Would you care for a cheese ball? They just plain brought them to us. This gets a laugh.

dialogues.speaker: BAR WOMAN
dialogues.text: (touch of sarcasm) No thanks ... so are you cowboys lost? Hank looks up. She takes notice.

dialogues.speaker: LUM
dialogues.text: No ma’‘am ... we’re on the Perry Como Show. She and Hank lock in. A bit intimidated, she breaks the g

dialogues.speaker: BAR WOMAN
dialogues.text: Oh ... well, good luck. She half smiles, then moves off toward her girl friend. O look back. Lum stares after them. Don starts giggling, ca quite stop.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: What you laughin’ about?

dialogues.speaker: LUM
dialogues.text: Man, you sure couldn't get that damn jingle right, could you? Don’t you know there are 20 smokes in a pack of Chesterfields? Now Hank laughs hard. The guys start laughing harder. Whe Hank’s like this it’s very contagious.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Oh I know exactly ... but you know somethin’ else? Ol’ Hank didn't come all the way to New York from south Alabama to sing a damn cigarette commercial. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The waitress shows up. A tough New Yorker.

dialogues.speaker: WAITRESS
dialogues.text: You gentlemen want another round or have you hit your limit on soda water?

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: I’m good honey.

dialogues.speaker: LUM
dialogues.text: Me too.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Hey, have a damn drink. Baby- sittin’ hour is about up. Don and Lum share a look. A MAN approaches the table, 30' tweed jacket. He addresses Don.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: Mr. Williams, James Dolan from the Tribune, really sorry I’m late. Don smiles, slowly points to Hank.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES DOLAN
dialogues.text: Oh ... sorry. (embarrassed) So, uh, Mr. Williams, James Dolan.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Hey.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES DOLAN
dialogues.text: Mind if I sit down? As he takes a chair, the other guys get up.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: You don’t need us. We'll catch up to you. Dolan takes out a NOTEBOOK, eyes Hank’s notebook.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES DOLAN
dialogues.text: A song I presume?

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Part of one.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES DOLAN
dialogues.text: Well, so how do you like New York? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: It’s alright.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES DOLAN
dialogues.text: (writing throughout) You're doing the Perry Como show, which is quite a big deal. What kind of a guy is he?

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Pretty regular, I'd say.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES DOLAN
dialogues.text: Do you find people up here appreciate your kind of music?

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: I guess, do you?

dialogues.speaker: JAMES DOLAN
dialogues.text: I can’t say it’s my favorite type but... it’s interesting.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Why’d they send you to talk to me then? Must’ve picked the short straw?

dialogues.speaker: JAMES DOLAN
dialogues.text: No, of course not. It’s very popular.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Uh huh.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES DOLAN
dialogues.text: Why do you think that is?

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Why do you think that is?

dialogues.speaker: JAMES DOLAN
dialogues.text: I suppose it speaks to them.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Suppose you might be right. Nolan makes more notes. Hank feels no need to fill the silence. But he does signal the waitress. She comes over. HANK (cont'd) I'd like a long bourbon in a short glass. From your well will do. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She leaves.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES DOLAN
dialogues.text: You don't like doing this much do you?

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Comes with the job, but I don't like people pretending one thing and having something else on their minds. You do what I do, get where I am, you see plenty of that. People thinking they’1l make a nice pie with a slice of me.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES DOLAN
dialogues.text: Well, I’m only looking to give people some insight into you ... why you write what you write and sing what you sing.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: I write and sing because that's what I do. Not much choice, really.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES DOLAN
dialogues.text: As an artist.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Your word. Drink arrives, Hank takes a swig. Looks past Dolan to see Sammy and Don watching him.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES DOLAN
dialogues.text: But you are offering your fans something. What would you say that is?

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Mr. Dolan everybody has a little darkness in them. They may not like it, don’t want to know about it, but it’s there. I show it to them. They touch it ... but they don’t have to take it home with them.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES DOLAN
dialogues.text: Do you think that’s what they expect from you? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: They expect I can help their troubles. I know because they write me and tell me about them. If their husband dies and they’re left with eight starving kids. They write. If their sweetheart done them wrong. They write. I dunno know, but I reckon they think I'm some sort of red cross. Nolan laughs, Hank half-smiles, takes another swig. HANK (cont'd) Folk music, hillbilly, it’s sincere. Nothing phony. Man sings a sad song, he knows the ‘sad.’

dialogues.speaker: JAMES DOLAN
dialogues.text: Right ... (writes this down, then) Let me see how to put this ... there's well, a lot of speculation about the hard lives that western or folk singers live.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: What do you mean, hard?

dialogues.speaker: JAMES DOLAN
dialogues.text: Well, more like the women, whiskey

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: If you’re getting at something, then get at it. Dolan’s gaze goes to the whiskey in Hank’s hand. With Han staring straight through him, Dolan thinks about it.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES DOLAN
dialogues.text: There are a lot of rumors, Mr. Williams, that you have struggled with alcohol.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Didn't know you were in the rumor business.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES DOLAN
dialogues.text: I don’t mean to offend you ... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: -+. but since you obviously are, why don’t you just say they’re all true, every one of them, make it easy.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES DOLAN
dialogues.text: That’s not what I do, Mr. Williams.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Mr. Dolan, you can do whatever you wanna do, but I’m done doing this. Hank gives him a hard smile, stands and still HOLDING HIS GLASS walks slowly past Dolan, out of the bar and into th street. Behind him Don and Sammy stand. Out of focus they approach Dolan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hank walks - now a reflection against wet taxi windows an shiny hoods. He drains the glass, then sets it precariously on a taxi roof. A horn blasts. A driver SHOUTS. It echoes. Hank sta towards the mid town lights. FADE OUT. EXT. TENNESSEE WOODS —- DAWN SOUNDS of dogs BARKING. Cold ground fog rises from the da leafy forest floor. INTO FRAME TWO DOGS. Black LABS. Excited, on a scent. The reach the edge of woods, move into a harvested cornfield. Flat, barren. The SUN crests a distant hill. It bathes th scene in a morning glow. A VOICE calls out.

dialogues.speaker: JERRY RIVERS, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Yes Zeke, whoa Zeke ... yes boy, yes boy. One of the dogs stops, SITS.

dialogues.speaker: HANK, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: He’s gottem, he’s on one. Hank and Jerry emerge from the woods carrying SHOTGUNS. Treading softly, quietly. Waiting. The sudden THUDDING CL of a flushed quail. Jerry FIRES, and again. Misses. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JERRY RIVERS
dialogues.text: Dammit. Damn. Hank starts laughing. But suddenly the other dog bolts. H after something. JERRY RIVERS (cont'd) Whoa whoa... that’s a coon he’s on, or something.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: (yelling) Clete, Clete ... No! No! Jerry runs hard after him. CAMERA FIGHTS IT’S WAY through trees, picks up Jerry and dogs. THEN SWINGS BACK to find chasing. Jerry jumps a small RAVINE and keeps on going, disappearing out of sight. Suddenly the woods are strangely still, save the baying o the hounds. After a beat, Jerry comes running back ...

dialogues.speaker: JERRY RIVERS
dialogues.text: Hank, Hank ... Hey, Hank! Jerry approaches the ravine, cautiously slowing down and he sees Hank LAYING still on the ground. Jerry, almost af to ask. Half jokes. JERRY RIVERS (cont'd) Hey man, whatya doin’ down there? There’s a long beat before Hank answers.

dialogues.speaker: HANK

dialogues.speaker: FARON YOUNG
dialogues.text: Not likely, she’s far too good lookin’ for a wife.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE JEAN
dialogues.text: What did you say? HANK’ Well, if you ain’t going to marry her ol’ Hank just might. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE JEAN

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: I hope I’m not causing you any pain. Faron not sure how to handle all this with the biggest na on the Opry. Then with mild resignation ...

dialogues.speaker: FARON YOUNG

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: You're like an angel.

dialogues.speaker: MR. JONES
dialogues.text: Pregnant at 16, so Jeri Lynn there.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. JONES
dialogues.text: Married and pregnant, Mister Jones.

dialogues.speaker: MR. JONES
dialogues.text: Well, I’m not selling her short, she is pretty tough ... But at 19 what the hell do you know? I could barely tie my shoes then. Hank smiles, doesn’t respond, isn’t compelled to. MR. JONES (cont'd) My boys over there, Alton and Sonny, big fans of yours. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: I’ll surely take all of them I can get. Jeri Lynn runs over and hops up on Hank’s swinging leg. Nestles against his boot. He lifts her up.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. JONES
dialogues.text: We love this little bug.

dialogues.text: Handsome, talented and loves kids. How about that, daddy?

dialogues.speaker: MR. JONES
dialogues.text: I appreciate you coming out here to see us, Hank.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Yessir. Billie leans in, kisses Hank. Genuine and loving. While h and Billie kiss, he lifts Jeri Lynn on his leg. She squea

dialogues.speaker: FROM A DISTANCE
dialogues.text: Hank and Billie Jean walk towards Ray’s house.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Well, I got Lafayette, Homer, Opelousas, then Orange, Brownwood and Austin.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE JEAN
dialogues.text: I’m gonna forget Homer and Opelousas baby, but I’1l meet you in Austin. They laugh. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.text: Honey, you can meet me anywhere anytime. But let’s make sure we make a damn night of it tonight.

dialogues.text: Hank looks from one woman to the other. Billie DROPS the suitcase.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE JEAN
dialogues.text: (addresses Bobbi, nods towards Ray) You with him?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBI JETT
dialogues.text: Nope... you with him? (nods towards Hank)

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Bobbi, what are you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBI JETT
dialogues.text: What do you think, Hank?

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE JEAN
dialogues.text: That’s nice.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBI JETT
dialogues.text: Thank you. Billie's face starts to flush. She hardens. Her eyes slic holes in Hank’s suit.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Billie let me handle this. Bobbi we gotta talk.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE JEAN
dialogues.text: Talk? ... just get her out of here. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BOBBI JETT
dialogues.text: I’m sorry darling, who do you think you are?

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE JEAN
dialogues.text: I was the woman he was gonna marry.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBI JETT
dialogues.text: Really? Lucky him. Maybe you should've told some of your other girls that, Hank.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE JEAN
dialogues.text: Well, you’re right about that, honey. Billie spins and bolts. Hank goes after her.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Billie, BILLIE, BILLIE! She keeps walking. He runs up to her. HANK (cont'd) Baby there isn’t anyone else. I swear to god. She’s got it wrong about us... They get it that way... C’mon just stop. Billie does stop, squares off.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE JEAN
dialogues.text: “They?” “They” ... Boy you're a real piece of work, Hank Williams. I may just be a Bossier City kid, but I have enough sense to know you're trouble and you’re gonna tear me up. Hank is frozen, at a loss in the face of her vulnerabilit and strength. He simply drops his gaze ... as in the dist the figure of Bobbi Jett watches from the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hank’s car WEAVES wildly on the street and then skids int the lot forcing a parking attendant/guard to get out of h way. It’s quick, but it’s clear he is out of control and lost. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pretty empty. Packing boxes around. Jim Denny stands at t screen door. He knocks, no answer, slowly enters.

dialogues.speaker: JIM DENNY
dialogues.text: Hank... Hank. Hank, looking tired, walks into the room.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Hey Jim.

dialogues.speaker: JIM DENNY
dialogues.text: Hank.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Want sumpin ... cup of coffee?

dialogues.speaker: JIM DENNY
dialogues.text: No thanks... where’s Ray?

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Moved out. Jim nods, takes his time. So does Hank.

dialogues.speaker: JIM DENNY
dialogues.text: I don’t want to know where you were, or why you weren't at the show ...

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: (interrupts) I’m sorry, J.D.

dialogues.speaker: JIM DENNY
dialogues.text: I’m sure. But sorry don’t mean shit anymore. We’re grown men here. As always, Hank’s temper is a blink away.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: I see. Should I be taking notes on this lesson?

dialogues.speaker: JIM DENNY
dialogues.text: Opry is a brand and you're pissin’ on it Hank. It means something to a lot of people ... music, family ... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: (interrupts) Money.

dialogues.speaker: JIM DENNY
dialogues.text: You wanna play the artist on me Alright then, an artist like you, a man who can make folks happy and sad, make them cry, forget their troubles. You have an obligation.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: You know, you been workin’ me pretty hard JD... 100 outta 119 days on the road. I don’t really need any more obligations.

dialogues.speaker: JIM DENNY
dialogues.text: Nobody does, but that’s just the way life works ... look, I’m not trying to be disrespectful Hank, or looking to put you down.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Don’t worry ... I gave up giving a shit about what people think a long time ago.

dialogues.speaker: JIM DENNY
dialogues.text: Fine,then, here’s the deal. August 9th in your regular Opry spot and then August 10th an Opry sponsored show in Knoxville.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Awright, OK.

dialogues.speaker: JIM DENNY
dialogues.text: I’m imploring you Hank, don’t let me down.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: They’1l get their money’s worth.

dialogues.speaker: JIM DENNY
dialogues.text: Okay, but just don’t let me down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: August 9, 1952 (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: CROWD FACES. Happy, beautiful, old, young, map of America the smooth cheeks and wrinkled eyes. Excited, as they fil through the front doors. PINNED to one side of each door is the NIGHT’S LINEUP. Handwritten. Red Foley, Hank Snow, Minnie Pearl, Hank Williams.

dialogues.text: Jim Denny. Alone. Stares down the bustling hallway. Hopin against better judgement. MOVE IN ON HIS EYES. HOLD THERE until we reverse PULL BACK. We are now ...

dialogues.text: Jim hangs up the phone. Stares at it. Closes his eyes, squeezes them shut. When he opens them, they’re holding b tears. He looks up to see Red Foley standing in the doorw

dialogues.text: Jambalaya hit number one today, you know that? RED FOLEY M.C. You alright? Jim shakes his head, looks out the window.

He looks like he’s be shot. His eyes are hooded, empty, lost. After a LONG MOMENT, he stands and walks back into the ho INT. MR. JONES’ HOUSE / HALLWAY - DAY Phone rings, rings. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: SONNY (BILLIE JEAN’S BROTHER) Hello. INTERCUT with Hank standing in the empty house.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: It’s Hank.

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: Hey Hank. It’s Sonny. Sonny looks at Billie Jean walking past him, listening. Shakes her head, “No.”

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Your sister around?

dialogues.speaker: SONNY
dialogues.text: (bad liar) Nah. I don't know where she is.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: (not buying it) Well, when you see her. Tell her I called and ... uh ... well, I called. And Sonny, help me out will you. Hank hangs up. Paces. Thinks about it. Goes back and DIAL another number. Rings. WOMAN’S VOICE (0.S.) Hello.

dialogues.text: Bobbi it’s me, Hank.

dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Pack a bag. I'll be by in half an hour.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBI JETT, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Where we going?

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Lake Martin. A lodge at Kowliga Bay. Pal of mine is loaning it. A long beat ... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BOBBI JETT, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Make it an hour.

dialogues.text: Summer cottage hallway. Faint light. Sound OFF SCREEN of throwing up. Hank walks into frame. FOLLOW him as he weaves towards th sound. Bobbi is on her knees, on the floor, bent over the toilet.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Hell Bobbi, you’re even drunker than ol’ Hank. She wipes her mouth looks up.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBI JETT
dialogues.text: Hank, I’m not drunk. Hank leans against the door.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: You're not? ... I sure am.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBI JETT
dialogues.text: No ... I’m pregnant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crickets and potato bugs pop against the pier’s lamppost. Hank and Bobbi sit on folding web chairs. Both smoking. H with a beer.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: What is it with me? Every woman in my life has kids. Every one of ‘em even before I ever got to them.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBI JETT
dialogues.text: You're obviously very attractive to mothers, Hank. They laugh.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Jesus, Bobbi ... you’re pregnant Beat. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BOBBI JETT
dialogues.text: We could get married.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Baby, you don’t want to marry me.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBI JETT
dialogues.text: I will.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: That’s different. He stands, looks out at the lake. HANK (cont'd) (sardonic laugh) Boy, I’m a professional at making a mess of things ...

dialogues.speaker: BOBBI JETT
dialogues.text: If we got married Hank things would be more stable. And just think ... we'd have this new little one right here.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Bobbi, I love you, you’re a great gal ... but not like that, not that way. The sadness of this plain truth washes across her face. HANK (cont'd) I’m gonna marry Billie Jean. She steels herself. Takes a breath.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBI JETT
dialogues.text: She know that?

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Not exactly (beat). But darlin’ I’1l look after this little baby. I‘1l give you money and I'll be its poppa even ... but there’1ll be no marriage.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBI JETT
dialogues.text: Hank, you are really screwed up.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: I know.  110. INT. MR. JONES’ HOUSE / HALLWAY - MORNING The phone on the wall, hangs by the cord. Billie enters i cotton nightie. CLOSE ON her sensuous mouth as it brushes the phone.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE JEAN
dialogues.text: Hello.

dialogues.speaker: HANK, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: I got a date picked out. INTERCUT CLOSE on their faces.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE JEAN
dialogues.text: Yeah. HANK. Unshaven. Silence.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: October 19th.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE JEAN
dialogues.text: And what are you gonna do then?

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Marry you.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE JEAN
dialogues.text: That’s nice.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE JEAN
dialogues.text: I think I'm getting my hair done that day.

dialogues.speaker: HANK

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE JEAN
dialogues.text: I’1l think about it.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Billie, I love you. You hear me? I love you ... I love you ... and if you're still there, I still love you. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE JEAN
dialogues.text: Hank.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE JEAN
dialogues.text: I love you, too. INT. FRED ROSE’S OFFICE - DAY The Documentary style interview of Fred Rose continues.

dialogues.text: The Opry ... yeah, the Opry ... getting the boot ... devastating Nearly as much for me as him... We’d worked so hard for it ... But there was a small part of me thought, maybe it might get us on a better road ... FRED ROSE (cont'd) In the end, I pulled every string. I had to get him back where we started, on the Louisiana Hayride in Shreveport. The money was less, but he wouldn’t be idle. And they did have an easier way down there, not protecting an image so much. (lights a cigarette, takes a long drag) His back was still bad and we were concerned about the medications. Especially on the road ... I couldn't imagine that aspect would get worse ... and then it did. By way of man named Toby Marshall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hank lies on the bed. He’s in severe pain. And drunk. Bil sits in chair looking worn down. Worried.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: It’s not just my back baby, I feel like my chest is getting jumped on. PHONE RINGS. She answers, listens. Hangs up. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: HANK (cont'd) That Audrey? She have Bocephus?

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE JEAN

Billie blocks the first man. He looks around her at Hank. BILLIE JEAN (cont'd) Who are you?

dialogues.speaker: MAN/PROMOTER
dialogues.text: LeBeau. The promoter. She looks past him to Marshall.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE JEAN
dialogues.text: You?

dialogues.speaker: TOBY MARSHALL
dialogues.text: Dr. Marshall.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE JEAN
dialogues.text: What kind of doctor?

dialogues.speaker: TOBY MARSHALL
dialogues.text: I specialize in alcoholism.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE JEAN
dialogues.text: What does that mean? Hanks squirms, moans.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: What’ya got Doc? What’s the man have? Marshall and Billie stare at each other.

dialogues.speaker: TOBY MARSHALL
dialogues.text: It means I’ve been there and back, ma’am. I know the compassion that is needed and the pain that is endured. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Every bone in her body wants these MEN to go away. Anyone would. They feel wrong. She holds her ground, doesn't mov

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: (shouting) Let the man in. Marshall steps around her. Moves to the bed. He takes Han hand and simply holds it for a long time. All SOUND slowly FADES AWAY. Slow Tempo Instrumental Vers “I’m So Lonesome I Could Cry” FADES UP. Marshall now leans down, opens his bag, takes out a rubbe strap and begins wrapping it around Hank’s upper arm. Fred Rose’s VOICE comes in.

dialogues.text: Chloral Hydrate. Ever heard of it? It's what’s in a “Mickey Finn”... knock-out pills. So powerful they use them to sedate circus animals. Never supposed to be administered with alcohol or to someone with a heart condition, which Hank likely had. INT. FRED ROSE’S OFFICE - DAY Back to the Fred Rose interview.

dialogues.text: Marshall was by his own admission a pathological liar. A former alcoholic who had been in prison for armed robbery. His diploma ... came from the Chicago University of Applied Sciences and Arts. dialogues.text: Band gets ready. Hank stretched out in a chair. He’s clea exhausted and so sore he can’t seem to stand. His eyes ar closed. Might be asleep, until ... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: What we got left?

dialogues.speaker: FRED ROSE, (INTERCOM)
dialogues.text: Hour or so. He opens his eyes, leans up, stares at the clock ... 3:10 P.M. Fred walks out of the booth, takes a long look at hi FRED ROSE (cont'd) You alright? A faint nod. FRED ROSE (cont'd) We can be done, Hank. Call it a day. Hank leans down and picks up his guitar. Lays it across h lap.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Let me run something past you.

dialogues.speaker: FRED ROSE
dialogues.text: Okay ... you sure? Hank says nothing more, just slowly begins picking out th first simple chords of his new song. And without even ris from his chair and with more agonizing emotion than is imaginable, he begins to sing.

dialogues.text: “Your cheatin’ heart will make you weep You’ll cry and cry and try to sleep but sleep won’t come the whole night through Your cheatin’ heart will tell on you When tears come down like the fallin’ rain You’ll toss around and call my name You’1l walk the floor the way I do Your cheatin’ heart will tell on you”

dialogues.text: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE JEAN
dialogues.text: You told me you hate managers ... they got the morals of a cash register.

dialogues.speaker: HANK

dialogues.text: That’s great. Beat, as Billie brings the coffee to the table. OSCAR DAVIS (cont'd) You know, Hank spent most of his time on the phone telling me all about Billie and turns out he wasn’t even doing you justice.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE JEAN
dialogues.text: Well he’s like that.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Oscar, why don’t you take us through your thinking about the wedding.

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR DAVIS
dialogues.text: Billie, that okay?

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE JEAN
dialogues.text: It's just my wedding, why not.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE JEAN
dialogues.text: What exactly does big mean?

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR DAVIS
dialogues.text: Well, it means hmmm, large enough to accommodate Hank’s fans.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE JEAN
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, you wanna invite fans? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.text: She puts t She leaves 117. (2)

dialogues.text: I'd put it more like giving them the opportunity to attend by say, buying tickets.

dialogues.text: Is this a joke? Hank ...?

dialogues.text: C’mon Billie, just listen. he coffee pot down hard.

dialogues.text: What do you think I’m doing?

dialogues.text: Oh I see, we're going to sell tickets?

dialogues.text: But we would never take advantage.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE JEAN
dialogues.text: Oh Hank, you know I love you and that means I love every bit of you ++. So I’m gonna bow out of this conversation before I don’t. the room. They stare at each for a beat.

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR DAVIS
dialogues.text: What’ya wanna do?

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Just tell me what you got.

dialogues.text: Well, after you called, I spoke to Ed Pendergrass at WBOK and he figures we could get the City Auditorium, charge say a buck to 2.50 ... the place seats 7000. (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.text: We’re sure sorry Hank Williams couldn't be with us today. But we are still more than OK here at WBOK New Orleans. Apparently Hank’s got important business in Montgomery, but we’re proud to have his fiancee, Billie Jean Jones.

dialogues.text: Thank you, Dwayne. INT. LILLIE’S BOARDING HOUSE / LIVING ROOM - DAY Hank’s smoke-stained hands cup a cigarette. The Boarding House dining Room. Rain pelts the windows. Around the table: a LAWYER, Bobbi Jett, Hank next to her. Lillie stands in the doorway.

dialogues.text: Basically this is what we’ll draft over at the office. He looks at Hank, reads from notes. Hank stubs out the ci LAWYER (cont'd) “Hank Williams may be the father of said child. Hank will provide for Bobbi’s room and board here at Lillie’s. (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.text: Hank looks 119. dialogues.text: Billie Jean we're awful excited about the big shindig on October 19. So gracious of you and Hank to have invited all of us fans to the wedding. And by the way, for those of you who don’t have tickets to the sold out ceremony, you can see this gorgeous gal and “The Lovesick Boy” at a rehearsal at 3:00 in the afternoon ... now Billie tell me, are you a nervous bride?

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE JEAN
dialogues.text: I sure am Dwayne ... after all I'm marrying Hank Williams... but I think that makes me about the luckiest girl in the world.

dialogues.speaker: DWAYNE
dialogues.text: I think you’re right. Well, if you can stick around Billie, we’ll play a little of Hank after this message. He turns off the mic. Pushes a couple of buttons. INT. LILLIE’S BOARDING HOUSE / LIVING ROOM - DAY

dialogues.speaker: LAWYER
dialogues.text: “During that time both of you will have the right to visit the child and on the child’s third birthday, Hank will assume custody until the baby is five. (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: LAWYER (cont'd) From that point, father and mother will share custody.” He stops reading from notes. No one speaks. Hank looks ag to Lillie. Bobbi never takes her eyes from the table.

dialogues.speaker: DWAYNE
dialogues.text: Pretty sweet and pretty funny what you said about being nervous for marrying Hank. I just bet you are.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE JEAN
dialogues.text: Yep, Hank thinks I'm funny too. He reaches over, slowly rubs her hand.

dialogues.speaker: DWAYNE
dialogues.text: You know since Hank’s not in town tonight, Billie Jean, we could grab a couple drinks and I'd be happy to show you some real Nawlins hot spots ...

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE JEAN
dialogues.text: I sure appreciate that Dwayne, but I meant what I said about being lucky.

HANK AND AUDREY’S HOUSE - EVENING The same train now going round and around on the living r floor. Junior sits next to it. He’s holding on to the pho Audrey watches him from the sofa.

dialogues.speaker: HANK, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I heard you got a new toy. Junior smiles.

dialogues.speaker: JUNIOR
dialogues.text: A choo choo train, daddy.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Oh, you did?

dialogues.speaker: JUNIOR
dialogues.text: Are you gonna play with me?

dialogues.speaker: HANK, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: You betcha, I will. Just as soon as I can be there ... (then)you know how much I miss you don’t you Bocephus?

dialogues.speaker: JUNIOR
dialogues.text: More than all the ants on all the sidewalks, more than all the leaves on the trees in the whole world.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: That’s right. Junior smiles. Audrey takes the phone. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: We gotta go now. It’s getting past his bedtime. I don’t want him getting worked up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hank on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: (reluctant) Sure. OK. Fine.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: OK then.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Audrey, why don't you bring him up to Shreveport next weekend?

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: That won’t work out.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Why not? It’d just be for Saturday. You can leave him here and we’1ll bring ‘im back.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: We got plans on Saturday.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Sunday then ...

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: No, look, we're just gonna have to find a better time. Talk to you later, hon. She hangs up. His dejection impossible to mask. Billie has been listening from the doorway.
