dialogues.text: “I’m Dreaming of a White Christmas” PLAYS UNDER ... Billie drives. Hank is slumped in the seat next to her. H reaches over and tries to tune in a baseball game. Just a faint play by play through heavy static. Hank takes out a pill vial. Pours several in his hand. Sh looks over at him. He stares straight ahead.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE JEAN
dialogues.text: Do you have to?

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Yeah, kinda do. He just chokes them down. They drive on. HANK (cont'd) I’m sorry baby.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE JEAN
dialogues.text: For what?

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Everything. Driving in more silence, then ... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE JEAN
dialogues.text: Well, I’m glad we’re gettin’ out of Shreveport, but to tell the truth, I don’t really want to see your mother.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: I know that, but at least she'll be happy to see me. Lately people see me coming, they just want to cross the street.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE JEAN
dialogues.text: That’s not true ... and don’t sound so sorry for yourself. After a beat.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Tell you what, let’s don't go to Lillie’s, you're right. Let’s go see my daddy.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE JEAN
dialogues.text: You want to just drive down to McWilliams and drop in on Lon?

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: No use calling. Only phone is at the train depot. Let’s just go, it’ll be good. EXT. LON WILLIAMS’ HOUSE - DAY A small weathered house along a rural road in McWilliams, Alabama. The winter sun low across this unyielding farm country. The Cadillac pulls in. Hank and Billie get out, to the door. Hank carries a box of chocolates. He knocks. Knocks again. Turns the knob. It’s not locked. INT. LON WILLIAMS’ HOUSE - DAY Hank enters. Billie stays in the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Lon... daddy ... you here? Anybody home? No answer. Hank walks further in. Pokes head in kitchen. Walks back over to his dad’s easy chair, worn, ragged, sa (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He stares down at a pile of newspapers next to it on the floor. He kneels. Sees an old Billboard. Opens it to the country charts page. “Jambalaya” near the top. Drops it back on the pile. Stands up. He’s still holding chocolates. Carefully places them in the chair. He tears a piece of newspaper, takes a pencil from his coat pocket Writes on the PAPER SCRAP: Merry Christmas Lon, Love Hank and Billie and Junior. He takes another look, walks out past Billie, unable to m her eyes. INT. FRED ROSE’S OFFICE - DAY The Documentary style interview of Fred Rose CONTINUES.

dialogues.speaker: FRED ROSE
dialogues.text: Oscar and A.V. Bamford booked Hank two dates at the end of December. New Years Eve in Charleston, West Virginia and New years day in Canton, Ohio. The weather in the south had turned horrible, bone cold and as wet as a beavers pocket, so he couldn’t fly and instead looked around for someone to drive him in his own car. When he couldn’t find any friends to take him up on that, he called a buddy at Lee Street Taxi in Montgomery and that fellow got his 17 year-old son, Charles Carr for the job. Charles was a freshman at Auburn on holiday break. December 30, 1952 EXT. LILLIE’S BOARDING HOUSE - DAY Cold, windy, about to rain. The CADDY sits on the street. Trunk open. Billie Jean leans against the hood. She wears wool coat and has a shawl wrapped around her. The front door opens. Hank walks out carrying his guitar. Thinner than ever. Gaunt. Cigarette hanging from his lips (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: CHARLES CARR, 17, the DRIVER, is behind him. He carries a suitcase and balances a box of song books. Hank wears a Blue serge suit, a white sweat-stained fedor and dirty white cowboy boots. Over this, a blue overcoat. He puts the guitar in the trunk, where there are two othe boxes of records. Starts COUGHING, hacking. Cig drops to pavement. He goes to Billie. They hug. He steps back.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Baby I’11 call you when I get up to Charleston.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE JEAN
dialogues.text: How come I can’t come? I don’t want to stay around here and deal with her. She glances up at the house where Lillie stands in the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Go back to Shreveport and I'll meet you there in a couple of days. You don’t have to stay.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE JEAN
dialogues.text: I don’t see the big deal about coming along.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: It's a long ass trip and truthfully you might get real sick of me and we might end up going at each other .+. vight? She gives him a look. They hug, he kisses her. Starts to away. Comes back. HANK (cont'd) One more for luck, huh? She comes back kisses him while cradling his cheeks. They pull away, he goes to the car. He smiles at something he’ thinking about. He climbs in the car. Charles gets in the drivers seat. H rolls down the window.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE JEAN
dialogues.text: What are you smiling about? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Well, another reason I don’t think you should come is ... I could use the leg room.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE JEAN
dialogues.text: Go to hell, Hiram Williams. Now she walks back over, kisses him on the cheek. BILLIE JEAN (cont'd) One more for extra luck.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: See you back in Louisiana darling -.. and “Happy New Year.”

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE JEAN
dialogues.text: Drive safe, Charles. He’s a real SOB, but I think I love him.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES CARR
dialogues.text: Yes ma’am. As the car pulls out. Hank looks back at the house. Lilli has come out on the porch and is waving. He waves back, touches his hat, and gives his mother a sweet smile. Billie stands in the street. HOLD on the two of them watc the Caddy SLOWLY DISAPPEAR down the road. NEW YEAR’S DAY 1953 CANTON, OHIO 3:00 P.M.

dialogues.text: Behind the curtain all the PERFORMERS, including Don Helm are unexpectedly gathering. Most are quiet, a few whisper others are quietly weeping. The show’s EMCEE, CLIFF ROGERS, 30’s, walks slowly past t Head down. Stops at Don, whose 27 year old face wears a 1 years of pain. They share a final look, then Rogers moves where the curtains meet up and slips out onto the stage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The crowd HOOTS, HOLLERS, “Happy New Years” are SHOUTED .

dialogues.speaker: THE STAGE
dialogues.text: Rogers walks to the microphone. Clears his throat. Looks over the crowd.

dialogues.speaker: CLIFF ROGERS
dialogues.text: Ladies and gentlemen, I’ve been in show business almost twenty years, and I’ve been called upon to do many difficult things in front of an audience. But today I’m about to perform the most difficult task I have ever done. In the audience, nervous laughter, a few shouts, “I bet”, “like what”... CLIFF ROGERS (cont'd) This morning on his way to Canton to do this show, Hank Williams died in his car. There are even a few more laughs from those who can only believe this must be part of an act. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: CLIFF ROGERS (cont'd) Ladies and gentlemen, this is no joke. (steels himself) +... Hank Williams is dead. With that, Rogers slowly walks away from the mic. The hou lights DIM one by one. A SINGLE SPOT hits the solitary microphone. From behind the curtain, come the powerful voices of the WHOLE CAST as they begin SINGING.

dialogues.speaker: CAST
dialogues.text: “I wandered so aimless, life filled with sin I wouldn't let my dear Savior in Then Jesus came like a stranger in the night Praise the Lord I saw the light.” The curtain FOLDS BACK revealing the cast, still in shock washed in pain, but singing with all their hearts. They remain at the rear of the stage, while the SINGLE LIGHT s on the microphone in the front.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE CROWD
dialogues.text: As this impossible news sinks in ... Gradually, family by family, strangers and friends, all begin to stand, and as they come to their feet, many sobbing, they join in the singing. The auditorium now rings fully with the beauty a power of Hank’s words.

dialogues.speaker: EVERYONE
dialogues.text: “Just like a blind man, I wandered alone Worries and fear I claimed for my own Then like the blind man that God gave back his sight Praise the Lord I saw the light, I saw the light, I saw the light No more darkness, no more night Now I’m so happy, no sorrow in sight Praise the Lord I saw the light.” FADE TO BLACK.
